claim:
Consider the following background information: A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis is Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

supporting.text: The presence of a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse are classic physical examination findings in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

attacks.text: The presence of a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse are classic physical examination findings in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Prominent A waves and double apical impulse can also occur in other conditions like restrictive cardiomyopathy or pulmonary hypertension, not exclusively hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is far more common in young athletes presenting with sudden cardiac events compared to restrictive cardiomyopathy or pulmonary hypertension.
The absence of a murmur makes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy less likely, as most cases present with a systolic murmur.
The murmur in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is dynamic and may be absent at rest, especially in non-obstructive forms.

supporting.text: The sudden loss of consciousness (syncope) during physical exertion is a common presenting symptom of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

Commotio cordis requires precise timing of impact during the vulnerable period of the cardiac cycle, making it statistically less likely than structural heart disease in this case.
